name: Five Stages of Grief
description: Identify how your character experiences grief using this popular model introduced by psychiatrist Elisabeth KÃ¼bler-Ross

attributes.name: Denial
attributes.description: How does your character express denial, the first stage of grief? Denial is a normal initial defense mechanism in the face of overwhelming grief (e.g. avoidance, confusion, numbness, shock).

attributes.name: Anger
attributes.description: How does your character express anger, the second stage of grief? Typically this anger stems from frustration that denial does not stop the grief. This stage may involve questioning who is to blame and why/how it could happen.

attributes.name: Bargaining
attributes.description: How does your character express bargaining, the third stage of grief? This is an attempt to find a compromise to escape the grief (e.g. "If you stop X, I will never do Y again.")

attributes.name: Depression
attributes.description: How does your character express depression, the fourth stage of grief? This stage is characterized often by sadness, overwhelm, silence, isolation, and moving away from loved ones.

attributes.name: Acceptance
attributes.description: How does your character express acceptance, the fifth stage of grief? Once the fog of depression has lifted, a state of calm settles in allowing them to accept their grief, make peace with it, and plan for the future.
